cs.IT, cs.CC, cs.SI, cs.DS, cs.LG. 

The paper deals with information theory and coding, which suggests that it belongs to the cs.IT (Information Theory) category. The paper specifically focuses on polar codes, which are a type of error-correcting code, and discusses their universality for different types of channels and sources. This suggests that it could also belong to the cs.CC (Computational Complexity) category, as the paper discusses the encoding and decoding complexity of polar codes. The paper also mentions maximizing mutual information, which is a topic in statistical inference, suggesting that it could belong to the cs.SI (Statistical Inference) category. Additionally, the paper discusses discrete memoryless channels, which are a type of probabilistic model, suggesting that it could belong to the cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) category. Finally, the paper discusses the error rate of polar codes, which is a topic in machine learning, suggesting that it could also belong to the cs.LG (Machine Learning) category.
